abstract.p: Howard Fussiner letter disputes list accompanying David Lehman's September 17 essay on best American poems of 20th century (S)

block.p: Regarding ''Top of the Charts,'' the list that accompanied David Lehman's essay ''All-Century Team'' (Sept. 17), about the best American poems of the 20th century: no Marianne Moore; no Theodore Roethke (where is ''I Knew a Woman Lovely in Her Bones''?); no Robert Lowell or Robert Penn Warren; no ''Howl'' (poor Allen); no Denise Levertov (''The Olga Poems''); no Charles Olson, Robert Creeley or Robert Duncan; no Galway Kinnell; no Adrienne Rich; no Muriel Rukeyser.

I was surprised to see James Schuyler up there, but maybe I underrate him. Gertrude Stein is arguable. Surely Robert Frost's ''Home Burial'' and ''West-Running Brook,'' mentioned in the essay, are greater poems than ''After Apple Picking'' and ''Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening,'' popular as the last two are.
But it's all good fun. Thank you for it.
